title: Erdős #100: Point Sets with Restricted Distances
description: Let A be n points in ℝ² with all pairwise distances ≥ 1 and any two distinct distances differing by ≥ 1. Must the diameter be ≫ n? Known: n^(3/4) (Kanold), n/log n (Guth-Katz). Piepmeyer: 9 points with diameter < 5.

overview.historicalContext: Erdős posed this problem in the 1990s as part of his extensive work on distance problems in discrete geometry. The problem connects to Erdős #89 (distinct distances problem), which was famously solved by Guth and Katz in 2015. Piepmeyer's construction of 9 points with diameter < 5 shows the conjectured bound cannot be too strong.
overview.problemStatement: Let A be a set of n points in ℝ² such that all pairwise distances are at least 1 and any two distinct distances differ by at least 1. Is the diameter of A ≫ n?
overview.proofStrategy: We formalize the restricted distance property, diameter, and the known bounds. Key results include Kanold's n^(3/4) bound, the Guth-Katz n/log n bound (via distinct distances), and Piepmeyer's counterexample to diameter ≥ n-1.
keyInsights: Distances are forced to be positive integers: 1, 2, 3, ...
Guth-Katz: distinct distances ≫ n/log n implies diameter ≫ n/log n
Piepmeyer: 9 points with diameter < 5 (counterexample to n-1)
Conjecture: diameter ≥ n-1 may hold for large n

conclusion.summary: This formalization captures Erdős Problem #100 on point sets with restricted distances. The question asks whether the diameter must grow linearly with n when distances are positive integers.
conclusion.implications: The problem connects discrete geometry to the distinct distances problem. Guth-Katz's breakthrough on distinct distances provides the current best lower bound of n/log n. The gap between this and the conjectured linear bound remains open.
openQuestions: Is diameter ≥ n-1 for large n?
What is the best constant in the linear bound?
Can Piepmeyer's construction be extended to larger n?
